quizzes.question: Which keyword is used to tell JavaScript that we're going to work with a variable?
quizzes.textContent:
[h1]Variables[/h1]

[b]Variables [/b]are containers for storing data values. The value of a variable can change throughout the program.
Use the [b]var [/b]keyword to declare a variable:[code format="js" ][b]var[/b] x = 10;[/code]
In the example above, the variable [b]x[/b] is assigned the value [b]10[/b].
[note]JavaScript is case sensitive. For example, the variables [i]lastName [/i]and [i]lastname[/i], are two different variables.[/note]

quizzes.question: What is the "=" (equal sign) called in JavaScript?
quizzes.textContent:
[h1]The Equal Sign[/h1]

In JavaScript, the equal sign (=) is called the "[b]assignment[/b]" operator, rather than an "equal to" operator.
For example, [b]x = y[/b] will assign the value of [b]y[/b] to [b]x[/b].
[note]A variable can be declared without a value. The value might require some calculation, something that will be provided later, like user input.
A variable declared without a value will have the value [b]undefined[/b].[/note]

[h1]Using Variables[/h1]

Let's assign a value to a variable and output it to the browser.[code format="js" codeId="647"]var x = 100;
document.write(x);[/code]
[b]Result:[/b] [img id="2740" width="100%"]
Using variables is useful in many ways. You might have a thousand lines of code that may include the variable x. When you change the value of x [b]one time[/b], it will automatically be changed in [b]all places[/b] where you used it.
[note]Every written "instruction" is called a [b]statement[/b]. JavaScript statements are separated by [b]semicolons[/b].[/note]

quizzes.question: What characters can be used to start a variable?
quizzes.textContent:
[h1]Naming Variables[/h1]

JavaScript variable names are case-sensitive. 
In the example below we changed x to uppercase: [code format="raw" codeId="648"]var [b]x [/b]= 100;
document.write([b]X[/b]);[/code]
This code will not result in any output, as x and X are two different variables.

Naming rules:
- The first character [b]must be[/b] a letter, an underscore (_), or a dollar sign ($). Subsequent characters may be letters, digits, underscores, or dollar signs.
- Numbers are [b]not allowed[/b] as the first character.
- Variable names[b] cannot [/b]include a [b]mathematical or logical operator [/b]in the name. For instance, [i]2*something[/i] or [i]this+that[/i];
- JavaScript names [b]must not contain spaces[/b].
[note]Hyphens are not allowed in JavaScript. It is reserved for subtractions.[/note]

quizzes.question: What characters cannot be used in variable names?
quizzes.textContent:
[h1]Naming Variables[/h1]

There are some other rules to follow when naming your JavaScript variables:

- You [b]must not[/b] use any [b]special symbols[/b], like [i]my#num,[/i] [i]num%[/i], etc.
- Be sure that you do not use any of the following JavaScript reserved words. [img id="2741" width="100%"]
[note]When you get more familiar with JavaScript, remembering these keywords will be much easier. [/note]
